Appendix 3: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

This document provides guidance for the management of the newly diagnosed child/young person with proven or suspected diabetes mellitus who is not in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) or after management and treatment of DKA when insulin injections are being initiated.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individual.
(Refer to Appendix 3)
Scope
These guidelines are for the use of all staff caring for children and young people within the Trust.
Many children with new onset diabetes are well and do not require management as per Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA ICP) Protocol.
These guidelines are for the newly diagnosed non DKA child/young person, or child who has recovered from DKA initiating subcutaneous insulin treatment.
Admission Policy
Any child referred with a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus should be seen on the same day on Phoenix Ward.
General Management
Admit to ward, explain that the purpose of the admission is to confirm the diagnosis, initiate treatment and start to educate the child and family in how to manage a child with diabetes.
It is very helpful to take a comprehensive family history including parents' names and occupations and of course any history of endocrinopathies / autoimmune conditions.
Confirm the diagnosis.
(If in any doubt, discuss with Consultant Paediatrician)
Perform the following investigations:

Blood glucose – essential to confirm high capillary blood readings – minimum 0.5ml in a fluoride oxalate (grey) bottle. Diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus is confirmed if random blood glucose more than or equal to 11mmol/l or fasting blood glucose more than 7.1 mmol/l;
HbA1c (EDTA bottle);
FBC, full biochemical profile and TFTs with thyroid (TPO) antibodies;
Coeliac screen (tTg antibodies), Islet Cell antibodies and Glutamic Acid Decarboxylase (GAD) antibodies;
Urine dipstick for ketones and glucose – please record results in notes even if negative;
Blood Ketones;
Mid-stream specimen of urine (MSU).
Weigh and measure the height of the child and plot on a centile chart
Commence insulin regimen:
Initial Insulin Dose Calculation for more than or equal to 5 years is 0.5-0.7 Units/Kg/Day;
Children under 5 years should be started on 0.5 Units/kg/day unless presented in DKA (start 1 Units/kg/day). If newly diagnosed diabetic was not in DKA, insulin requirements are lower;

Discuss with Consultant/Senior Paediatric Doctor the insulin regimen to be commenced. Novorapid or Apidra Cartridges may be preferred in toddlers because of the availability of half unit dosing using half unit pens.

If the child is nauseous or unwell, check a venous gas in addition to investigations above – if acidotic (pH less than 7.25 and bicarbonate less than15) treat as DKA. If blood ketone more than 3 mmol/L, treat as DKA.
It is important to give clear positive messages, support and advice to children/ families and young people.
Insulin Profiles

data.url: 11022 Child Newly Diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus 4.0.003.png

data.text: Insulin Regimen for all Ages

Children should commence on a basal-bolus regimen with prescriptive doses while diabetes education on carbohydrate counting is being arranged after discharge home. This regimen mimics the normal physiology of insulin production. The Diabetes nurses will ensure that the school has a care plan as children will have to inject at lunchtime.
Basal–bolus regimen is the recommendation from diagnosis.
Lantus Solostar (insulin Glargine) or Levemir - 40% of total daily dose. Lantus is given once a day and Levemir split into 2 doses  hours apart.
Apidra Solostar / Humalog Lispro or Novorapid® (insulin Aspart) – 60% of total daily dose divided between 3 main meals as below:-
30% before breakfast;
30% before lunch;
40% before evening meal (assuming this is the biggest carbohydrate intake of the day).
Prescribe Levemir or Lantus Solostar (check with Children's Diabetes Nurse
Specialist (CDNS), this is a prefilled pen device/cartridges, which are easy to use.
Novorapid is given by flexpens (disposable) or cartridges;
Lantus Solostar /Apidra Solostar as disposable pens ;
If child is less than 5 years old, prescribe Levemir and Novorapid cartridges for Novopen Echo for half unit dosing.

When the children start on basal bolus regimen the short acting insulin i.e. NovoRapid / Apidra Solostar / Humalog Lispro should be given with main meals. Long acting insulin i.e. Lantus is usually given at bedtime, Levemir in split doses 12 hours apart.
Lantus/ Levemir insulin should be given at night within a 1 hour window (e.g. between 7- 8pm, CDNS or medical staff will discuss with parents/child/young person).
Check blood sugar levels 5 times per day, pre-breakfast, pre-lunch, pre-tea, 2 hours post-tea and at 2am while inpatient.

Use a soft click pen device for blood sugar testing from the start. These are in the blood testing kit supplied with the meter (in the new patient pack). Use as low a setting as possible to prevent painful fingers.
Initially 5 blood glucose level tests a day (see below) until a clear pattern has been established.
The blood glucose level can run high between 10-20 mmol/l for the first 3-5 days. Please follow the insulin correction doses in the drug chart.
There is no need to routinely check blood sugars several times during the night unless they appear hypoglycaemic, or have had their first dose of insulin at bedtime.
Check blood ketones on admission to record a base line level and reassess the patient's need for more insulin or intravenous fluids.

After the first few days the blood sugar level target can be variable 4-15 mmol/l. The blood sugar level target range will be agreed individually at discharge. Target blood glucose 4-7mmol/L before meals is usually achieved after discharge from hospital and when blood sugars are stabilised, it may take several weeks.

There is flexibility at meal times with the basal/bolus insulin regimen. Insulin should be given immediately prior to eating. Snacks are not compulsory and should be taken according to natural hunger and predicted activity.
Start the education programme and checklist (refer to Appendix 2) for parents/ carers as early as possible.
CONTENTS OF DIABETES STARTER PACK (RUCKSACK) FOR FAMILY

table_items.text: Accu-chek Expert meter Accu-chek Fastclix lancet drums x 2 boxes Accu-chek Aviva Test strips x 1 box of 50 strips Control solution x 1 box Glucomen Areo ketone test meter & ketone strips CYP Diabetes Education Booklet
Blood glucose diary Red diabetes community folder Business card with telephone numbers for CYP Diabetes Team

data.text: Discharge
Write up medicines to take home (TTA's) on admission to have them ready for discharge. Only discharge the patient once patient and family are ready.
TTAs: Insulin depending on regimen either:
Levemir penfill 3 ml cartridges or Flexpens x 1 box;
or
Lantus Solostar 3ml Pre-filled pens or cartridges x 1 box;
or
Insulin Deglutec (Tresiba) penfill 3 ml cartridges or Flexpens x 1 box ;
and
Humalog Lispro Kwik pens or penfill cartridges x 1 box; or
Novorapid penfill 3 ml cartridges or Flexpens x 1 box; or
Apidra 3ml Pre-filled insulin half unit pens x1 box.
Plus:
Accuchek Fastclix lancets x 1 box;
Glucogel x 2 boxes;
Glucagen x 1 pack;
BD- 5mm or Novofine 4 mm needles x 1 box;
BD 5 mm autoshield safety needles if not self-injecting;
Glucomen Areo B-Ketone tests strips x 1 box;
Accuchek- Aviva Test strips x 2 boxes (check with meter given in the pack;
Sharps box small x.
The diabetic nurse will supply the blood glucose machines, if it has not already been provided from the starter pack.
Any advice regarding diabetes management as an inpatient needs to be discussed with a member of the Children's Diabetes team.
Differential Diagnosis

Type 1 diabetes – classic triad of polyuria, polydipsia and weight loss. High blood glucose levels with ketonuria signifying insulin deficiency. 95% or above of children presenting with suspected diabetes will have Type 1.

Type 2 diabetes – look for risk factors signifying insulin resistance i.e. obesity, ethnicity, family history, acanthosis nigricans. Hyperglycaemia tends to be mild rather than grossly elevated. Discuss with diabetic consultant.
Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY) – think of in mild hyperglycaemia, no evidence of insulin deficiency and a family history of DM in at least one parent. Discuss with diabetic consultant.
Stress Hyperglycaemia is associated illness.
Genetic syndromes accompanied by diabetes mellitus.
Staff Training
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
During induction process junior medical staff will receive instruction on current polices and guidelines.
At case presentation and junior doctor teaching will discuss diabetes cases and learn from the outcomes.

Where a patient's notes have demonstrated that the appropriate action has not been taken a ‘risk event form' is to be completed. This will address any further training needs for staff that requires updating.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention using Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when carrying out procedures.
Audit and Monitoring
Audit annually the management of newly diagnosed children with non DKA diabetes against this guideline.
Communication
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email after ratification of guideline.
References
ISPAD (International Society for Paediatric and Adolescent Diabetes) 2014 https://www.ispad.org/
ACDC (Association of Children's Diabetes Clinicians) http://www.a-c-d-c.org/

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2016) Diabetes (type 1 and type 2) in children and young people: diagnosis and management (NICE guideline NG18) Available at: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/NG18

DKA protocol  Correction dose of insulin Novorapid 0.1U/kg
Encourage oral fluids Deterioration/
DKA  Improving
DKA corrected
Eating and drinking  Start routine insulin when next injection would
be due

data.text: Levemir or Lantus® - 40% of total dose before evening meal (remember to split Levemir)
Humalog Lispro/ Apidra or Novorapid - 60% of tdd divided as:
30% before breakfast
30% before lunch
40% before evening meal
Don't forget to write up the TTAs !
